poem:
Beneath the Bramblered Braveshriek Glare

’Twas underclonking, and the slibberloam
did quankle in the gloomring dark;
All flimbridge was the dripdrone stone,
and the hushgrim shadows hark.

“Beware the Wyrdrumb, my brusk kin lad,
that howls where echo-slithers roam!
O flinch ye at the clatterclad—
it hunts the underpass for home.”

He took his slokenblade in grip,
he steeled his heart for grumbled strife;
Through rusted arch and chitter-pipe
he sought the reverb-spattered life.

Refrain-thrice the Wyrdrumb moaned,
its tailclad thunder shivered deep;
Each stalag-shard of sound intoned
a ghostly oath it could not keep.

One! Two! Off-key rebound!
The slokenblade went slurring back—
He left it thrumming in the ground,
stamped out the echo’s wailing track.

“And hast thou felled the Wyrdrumb’s cry?
Come tell it, child, to waiting sky!”
“O hush, no more: I’ve taught the roar
to hush in shards of dripdrone stone,
And underclonking eaves no more
let echoes breed or dreams bemoan!”

poem:
The Fog-of-Wock
Beware the mistywump, my child, that dandles on the dew,  
It slithers through the sleepygroves where whiffling dreams once grew;  
With murklesilk it cloaks the sun, a lolloping balloon,  
Till clockle-birds forget to chirp and chimneys snore till noon.  
Oh fasten up your flippity cap, lace boots of thistlebone,  
Take spoon of starlight, sprig of thyme, lest Fog-of-Wock intone.  

He left at break of yawnlet, whistling bright and bold,  
Through hushabye of hollow streets the fog had cupped and rolled;  
Past chimble-chumble market stalls where candle-cobwebs cling,  
He marched with pluck and peppermint the dawn would surely bring.  
He met the mizzly whiskersnout, the hogglebacked haze,  
He tickled it with gigglebranch and set the sky ablaze.  

Come caper home, O gallant one, the kettle’s gleeful jig,  
The mistywump gone scampering, adwindled to a twig;  
O frabjous day! Calloo! Callay! The roofs shine silver-blue;  
Our hearth a cake of candledawn, our laughter bubbles through.

The Déjàvoom of the Wyrm of Twice

The rewhirl wind did whirl,
When came a tread of twice-worn feet
That trod a trodden twirl.

“Beware the Déjàvoom, my child!
The blinkbeak, the rewyrm, the same!
The timeclawed claw, the mem’ry mild
That mutters back your name!”

He took his mindblade in his fist,
Went wading through the then—
Rested a spell by the whilom well
Where the past dripped once again.

And as in mimsy thought he stood,
The Déjàvoom, with eyes of yore,
Came slithering through the thistlewould,
Repeating what before.

One, twice! One, twice! The mindblade sliced,
Through echo, drift, and rhyme—
He left it dead, yet overhead
It lived a second time.

“And hast thou slain the Déjàvoom?
Come to my arms, my beamish doubt!
O frabjous loop!” He wept mid-whoop,
For it was inside-out.

’Twas duskled in the slipthrash glade,
The rewhirl wind did whirl—
When came a tread of twice-worn feet…
And round began to twirl.

poem:
The Glimmergrass Desire-Skeddath

’Twas twirlish in the glimmergrass, the vibbards all a-stray,  
did quorble, quorble through the fronds in quaintish disarray;  
Beware, oh tabbely tourist, keep thimbled boots held tight—  
a snirksome subble lurks beneath—lest footstep be benight!

She took her slanty runne-stick, a mappish scroll of dreams,  
and kithed across the velvet sedge with moon-lit hoplix beams;  
She sought the zyggered desire-path where footfall scorns the stone,  
where banshies of convention fade and mimsy rules are blown.

The path came swithling greenly, a low-brow skreek and roar—  
It warped like wibblewobble wood and looped with frekkled lore.  
She rumbled, fumbled, tumble-bounced—yet stayed upon the track;  
No bramble-bode, nor tickle-toad, could fling her wagon back.

One grumbly-swish! Two flittled whoosh! The hedge gave way to blue;  
And glimmergrass bowed quite away—three cheers for something new!  
Now foreheads glow of those who go where wish-line bents the sod;  
Desire wins, the routed grin—Oh tabbely gods be laud!

poem:
Cartographwocky

'Twas chartful, and the snipple-spanned  
On vellum veered in gryphing tide;  
All flitter-flapped the longituderand,  
And the meridionder sighed.  

“Beware the Mapfang, wanderchild!  
The maw that gulps uncharted lands,  
Its inkwell tongue, its compass wild,  
Its gnaw upon forgotten strands!”  

She took her gnomon-staff in grip,  
She sought the drifters’ rumor-hoard;  
She riddled grids on every ship,  
She bribed the wind with folded board.  

While parchment-wraiths in whirlpool blew,  
The Mapfang rose from crease-of-crease;  
Through latticed dusk and squall it drew,  
Inking out the paths of peace.  

Rift! Grapple! Cartographic bite!  
Lines splintered, legends fled the fray.  
She struck at scale with lantern-light,  
And lured the beast to broadest bay.  

As dawning spilled through merigraph  
(That glowing graph, untearable),  
The contours bent but did not break;  
The edges held—unbearable!  

“Beware the fold-fall, cartographist!”  
(The parchment choir sang anew),  
“For borders breathe, but never list—  
The world is redrawn within by you.”  

'Twas chartful, and the snipple-spanned  
Now glimmers where the dragon hid;  
All flitter-free the longituderand,  
And the meridionder did.

The Layobrisket Waltz of Layover Bay

’Twas blinky at the skyport-gate, the skyrails trundled by,
With buzzyflumps upon the tarmac that looped the cobalt sky,
Beware the Time-dragon’s yawn, my child, whose snores delay your wings;
Prepare your snack-portal pack, your pangum and your tings!

He took his wandringlaff in hand, long time he sought the gate,
Airstairs slinking, engines winking, promising to mate,
He waited in the whizzling chair, a nodeboard softly sang,
Then zipped! came Layover Bay in view—for which his spirit sprang.

Layobrisket! The vest-lounge ticked, where pilfins dunk and drowse,
Where nap-nooks bloom like jelly-moons and laugh-logs float their vows;
The caf-flight brews ambrosial foam with clacketty barista sound,
While time-lag ghosts and suitcase beasts go wobblin’ round.

He twirled a swirly spiral ramp down to the Sandglass Squall,
A mini-maze of minute-sand that tickled every wall,
And told the Watch-wyrm, “Set me free, release me to the sky!”
It hiccuped stars and stamped his pass—returner, do-not-die!

Returneth now, souffléed with cheer, the traveler skips in rhyme,
His pockets full of tick-tricks and a spoonful of lost time;
Oh frabjous joy, all delay be toy, now hug your seats and say,
We danced the Layobrisket waltz and whisked through Layover Bay!

poem:
The Monte-Carlo Chortlequest  

Beware the Casino’s clink-clank call, my bright,  
Where glamblings glimmer through the gilded night;  
The wheel-whirled stars of chance, the dice-dazzled light—  
Take heart, take chip, take nerve, and bind your purse-belt tight!  

He packed his luck in a silken case,  
With cufflinks carved of clover-sheen,  
A sprig of thyme for cunning grace,  
And a flask of midnight tangerine.  
“Come, gallant boy, the tables croon—  
Leave dullness to its droop and swoon!”  

Through marble mists of champagne breeze  
He skittered past the perfumed throng;  
Past velvet ropes and perfumed trees  
Where jazzjaws jived a jiggled song.  
The baccarat beasts with diamond claws  
Were scribbling scores on silver laws.  

Then, hush!—the room began to spin,  
The chandeliers in zircon showers;  
The roulette red like dragon skin,  
The felt-green fields of fortune’s flowers.  
One step, two step, click and clack—  
He laid his stake upon the black.  

“Spin, spin, you carbuncled wheel,  
Let stars align in spinning steel!”  
The croupier cried with crystal zeal—  
The marble sang a silver peal.  
Round and round the pill it flew,  
A comet in a velvet blue.  

With whoop and whirl and whiffling cheer  
It settled—black!—a victor’s dome;  
The watchers gasped, then burst to sheer  
Glimmergusts of glitter-gnome.  
The boy had slain the chance-wyvern—  
He flung his hat, “Return, return!”  

So back he came through neon noon,  
With pockets full of ruby rain,  
A garland woven from doubloon,  
And laughter like a bright champagne.  
“O come, my lads, and clink your cups—  
The Monte-Carlo moon is up!”

The Whisperscene of Curtained Gloam

The Borwnbutter Ballade

the nut-brown nargle’s scent!

to foaming life be sent.

a nose that knows the tune;  
for soon the gloam of milk-fat foam  
shall sing a darker rune.  

He stirred the burbling, twirching melt,  
he watched the foam subside;  
the crackle-croon of amber noon  
rose up in tawny tide.

the shadows sniffed for more—  
and lo! the brown-buttered Jabbercrust  
came dancing through the door!  

“O frabjous smell! O toasty spell!”  
he caroled, spoon in hand;  
he tipped the gleaming, beaming stream  
across the biscuit land.  
With crackle-snap and fizzle-flap  
the cookies turned to gold;  
each crumb a star from carameled skies  
that legends long have told.  

So home he came, through steam and flame,  
his apron rich with fame;  
he brought the hoard of Borwnbutter—  
and none shall scorch again!

The Skreechlurker’s Third-Rail Croon

’Bware the glimtrak’s joltvolt hum!
—It thrummeth in the drizledark, the tickle-buzz beneath our shoes—  
From gloam-bolt’s coppery vespers creep skreechlurkers, 
crouched in iron grot-lair, eye-lamps wick-sharp, spark-snarling.
Oh, the sizzlesnap of railtide thrills their marrow-coil!
Snorffle-buzz, the hummabone sings—krazzles!—where no moon dares whisper.

Take thee, traveler, a slitherspoon of rubber brine,
And wrap thy ticky-cloak in tramble-silence;
For should thy tinger-toe so slyly twitch the thrum-bar,
The zizzitox will coil up quicksilver ankles,
And skreechlurker Vzzril—he of six-coal tongue and volta-plume—

Snicker-blink! The signals glint—green, glum, gash!
A tram-crypt hisses, doors gape like iron grins.
Runny-runnel of darklight sloshes through the gridded gloam,
While the rail-throb mutters ooh-ah, ooh-ah—
Each pulse birthing violet hatchlings of raw surprise.
Yet mark thee well: beneath the flit-flick neon,
Old Vzzril’s tail-coils twitch; his drool-drips are volta-plasma honey.

Fear the zappasnatch, the tickle-zizz, the sudden sizzle-splash!
But should a brave-ling dare a twiddle-step too near,
Let her wield the clunk-muff mitten and the whistle-silk scarf,

Then clatter-dash, clatter-dash, through turnstile chirrup,

Lulls the skreechlurker back to copper-sleep.

’Bware the glimtrak’s joltvolt hum!
—It thrummeth in the drizledark; the tickle-buzz abides—  
Yet if the night’s blue lullaby should wobble and go slack,
Remember Vzzril’s spark-chant, flick-flick, flick-flick;
Count the hertz-burrs in your ribs,
And slip your soul-sled between thunderbeats,  
For every train is but a dream 
whose whistle wakes the sky.

Dwellwink of the Repeaterwraith
